body: I see this has already merged, but it would be good if we could get a test in for this as well. I'm not sure if the current ES schema used in the integration tests has any non-lowercase names though.
Sorry @michaelmior I was of the impression that you were already fine with the state and it seemed ok to me since the tests weren't failing. Should I revert it?

No problem :) If existing tests are passing, I'm not concerned. I think it's unlikely to be a nissue. It would just be good to ensure something like this doesn't pop up again in the future without us catching it.
Need to think more about this, taking the PR back for now

@beikov Did you do the merge?

Your name doesn't appear in the git metadata, which is weird:

```
$ git log --pretty=fuller -n 2
commit f8f38648ecd4cfb77f018deaeea435e09cadbd3d (HEAD -> master, origin/master, origin/HEAD)
Author:     Andrei <andrei@nospam.com>
AuthorDate: Thu May 17 13:04:24 2018 -0400
Commit:     Andrei <andrei@nospam.com>
CommitDate: Thu May 17 20:13:23 2018 -0400

    [CALCITE-2316] don't apply lowercase transformation to ES queries

commit 36b1d5c34f0f94cd95f832a0d9aa2e9f89210e1d
Author:     Jesus Camacho Rodriguez <jcamacho@apache.org>
AuthorDate: Mon May 14 14:53:57 2018 -0700
Commit:     Jesus Camacho Rodriguez <jcamacho@apache.org>
CommitDate: Mon May 14 14:53:57 2018 -0700

    [CALCITE-2309] Dialects: Hive dialect does not support charsets in constants
```

A couple of things I'd have done differently:
* Since the contributor is not a committer, make sure that the message ends with the contributor's name, " (Andrei Sereda)"
* Add "Close apache/calcite#NN" to the message, so that the PR gets closed.
* Mark the JIRA case "Resolved (fixed)".
* Ask the contributor to write a unit test (if possible).
Fixed in 446945c7. I had to force-push because I got the JIRA case number wrong in the first commit.
you will need a test, and some descriptions.
Just a brief comment that this shouldn't include the fix for CALCITE-3126 as well. (This may be a result of a force push that happened on master.)
Also, the two commits should be squashed together.

Ack, will fix this. I raised some questions on the dev list for the PR,
will update post the resolution on that.

Thanks for reviewing this PR, Michael and Zhen

the commit from the PR branch and pushed it, maybe it would report me when
I had altered the commit message.
I was looking for some guidelines on how to do this but couldn't find any.
Might be a good idea to create a little markdown file containing the
necessary steps.

I'd do it right now but I'm on vacation in the U.S. and will come back home
on June 10th. I'll add these instructions later if you don't mind.

Regards,
Christian

If you just merge the commit without any changes in a fast forward merge, the commit won't be modified and will still retain the original author information. There's nothing wrong with this IMO. Your name would be included if you had altered the commit message as you suspect.

@beikov Yes it would be great if you add to HOWTO.md

@michaelmior Makes sense; I should have realized that a fast-forward merge and a push don't change the git sha, so it's impossible for them to change any of the metadata.
Commit f8f3864 is not mine. Maybe it will vanish after I fix typos and rebase on master.
@michaelmior I've made patches and rebased on master
Please rebase this PR into a single commit with the message prefixed with `[CALCITE-873]`. Thanks!
@michaelmior Done, thanks
The commit message should be `[CALCITE-873] Add a rule to eliminate constants in Sorts`. This can be changed by whoever ultimately merges the PR, but should be done eventually for consistency.

Fixed both the comments On Wed, May 23, 2018 at 11:10 PM, Haisheng Yuan wrote: > *@hsyuan* commented on this pull request. > ------------------------------ > > In core/src/main/java/org/apache/calcite/rel/rules/ > SortRemoveConstantKeys.java > : > > > +import org.apache.calcite.rel.RelFieldCollation; > +import org.apache.calcite.rel.core.Sort; > +import org.apache.calcite.rel.metadata.RelMetadataQuery; > +import org.apache.calcite.rex.RexInputRef; > +import org.apache.calcite.rex.RexNode; > + > +import java.util.ArrayList; > +import java.util.List; > + > +/** > + * Planner rule that removes > + * a {@link org.apache.calcite.rel.core.Sort} if its input is already sorted. > + * > + *

Requires {@link RelCollationTraitDef}. > + */ > +public class SortRemoveConstantKeys extends RelOptRule { > > The convention is that every rule name ends with Rule. Other than that, > LGTM. > > — > You are receiving this because you authored the thread. > Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub > , > or mute the thread > > . > -- Regards, Atri *l'apprenant*
The existing `SortRemoveRule` serves a different purpose, which is to remove a `Sort` when the input is already sorted.
That doesn't appear to be the case to me, but one easy sanity check is to see that existing tests pass if `SortRemoveRule` is replaced with `SortRemoveConstantKeysRule`.

No, SortRemoveConstantKeysRule will not remove pre sorted orders, so
SortRemoveRule needs to exist

I see, but the 2 rules can be merged into 1. There is no need to have 2 rules to match sort twice.
+1 LGTM Thanks Francis!
What's the benefit of doing this (serious question)? If we don't have a good reason for doing so, I'd be inclined to wait until we drop JDK 8 support at some point in the future.

LGTM. You're always welcome to ask for review. But for small changes (especially those with tests), you are also free to commit directly to master :) (In general, filing a JIRA for anything non-trivial is still good though.)
+cc @jcamachor @b-slim : please review.
@nishantmonu51 i don't see the tests, plus i see there is some code changes unrelated, not sure what is happening really

@michaelmior valid question. html5 support for javadocs is really nice but does require JDK 9. One benefit of doing this now is we get earlier testing of javadocs against later JDKs with HTML5. Either way I'm not in a rush to merge this.

I'd suggest waiting until JDK 8 support is dropped. I think there's potential confusion that can be caused if there are two different sets of Javadocs that can be generated. Thanks for this regardless! I'm really -0 so if others feel keen to merge, that's fine with me.
@b-slim @jcamachor Please review.
Sounds goo to me!
Can we fix the test errors?
@beikov Can you weigh in on this given your recent work on the ES?
I'm still on vacation so I can only have a deeper look next week. Overall this looks ok though.

It looks like the comment about `ENABLED` at the beginning `MongoAdapterTest.java` is now incorrect. The tests are not just included in the integration profile anymore.

I have moved `ENABLED` flag to `MongoAdapterIT`.  There is still an edge case in the sense that `MongoDatabaseRule` will attempt to connect to the database even if `calcite.test.mongodb=false`. Tests will not run though. 

Is this an issue ?

If it's not too complicated to resolve, that would be good to fix. I don't think it's much of a practical concern though since it's always possible to exclude the mongodb project from testing which will have the same impact.
This was addressed in the last (squashed) commit.

Merged! Thanks for the contribution :)
merged.
With pleasure. It's the least I can do for such a wonderful framework.
Thanks for the updates! Merged.
Thanks slim, pushed to master

These planning changes look good.  I was wondering if you have looked into the run-time changes in the Calcite executor for this agg function (for example `MinMaxImplementor`) ?  I am not familiar with that part of Calcite.  Perhaps someone else can offer suggestions there.

Looks good to me now. Anything to add @michaelmior ?

This is similar to #734

Yes, the fix by this PR is included in #734.
I'll close this.
Thanks for the contribution! It would make things easier to review if you could squash those three commits down to one.

No major additional concerns here although we may want to hold off on merging this until after the next release. I'm not sure how heavily the ES adapters are used but this is a fairly big change and I wouldn't want to rush it.

@michaelmior  I also wanted to submit a patch for [CALCITE-2331](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2331) :  can't evaluate expression `(A or B) and C`.

Not sure about other users but it is pretty important to us. So we would rather see it merged sooner than later. Worst case, we can wait till next release probably.

@beikov regarding visibility. Before there were 3 ES-related packages:
1. elasticsearch (in `core` module)
2. elasticsearch2 (in `elasticsearch2 ` module)
3. elasticsearch5 (in `elasticsearch5 ` module)

Base classes located in `core` were mostly public / protected (so they could be extended in other packages). Now, all ES related classes reside in the same package so visibility can be reduced to package-private. 

Philosophically speaking I just prefer to minimize accessibility of classes and members and provide explicit access points. Should one field / method be required by clients, one can always increase the visibility, it is much harder to do the opposite.

@asereda-gs If it's occurring with multiple adapters, I assume it's unrelated to these changes, so I wouldn't be concerned about that. That would be a good bug to be fixed for the upcoming release if you can put a PR together.

@michaelmior Yes it's occurring with, at least, ES and Mongo.  But if I'm making a patch for [CALCITE-2331](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-2331) I'd rather do it against single branch. For instance, ES Query generation and execution depend on transport client and ES API being used.

@asereda-gs I would suggest making a patch against the branch for this PR. Once that's confirmed to work, we can try it on master as well and hopefully it works there and we can merge it independently. If not, we can discuss the best way to get everything in.
@chunhui-shi The discussion in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1748 has moved on to other implementation strategies. Can you please close this PR?
@tpanningnextcen Looks this PR is not going to get finished. Can you please close it?

@mindcrime Can you please close this PR? https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1025 has been marked a duplicate of https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CALCITE-1173, which was fixed in avatica-1.8. And in any case, this code has since been moved to the Avatica project.
Could you start by rebasing this PR into a single commit? It makes things quite a bit easier to review and would be done anyway before merging. Thanks!
I don't fully understand the implications of this change, but I can confirm it solves the performance problems with `RelMetadataTest#testPullUpPredicatesForExprsItr`.

Thank you @michaelmior for verifying that it solves the regression!

I don't wanted to expose this toggle outside of RexSimplify...
The feature is disabled at this point:
https://github.com/apache/calcite/pull/747/files#diff-5f0afa01652e21f36d8d4172f9af4dfeR1625
That method is only used from RelMetadata so its disabled only for that.

Thanks @michaelmior for checking.
I have squashed the commits and rebased from current master branch.
This fails to compile as you can see in the output of the Travis build.

Sorry for my fault.
I have modified the PR and checked `mvn clean package` finished successfully.
Confirmed that this builds fine for me now.

@michaelmior  I have created #753 (patch for (A or B) and C) based on this branch.
Let's discuss it.
Seems like the removal of `elasticsearch5/src/test/resources/log4j2.xml` should actually be part of #744?

Any idea how complicated it will be to fix `testFilterRedundant`? I'd certainly prefer to favour correctness over performance, but it would be good to get a sense of how challenging this would be to fix in the future.

Re `elasticsearch5/src/test/resources/log4j2.xml` it was modified as part of  4e93a82c. So I had to remove it explicitly.

For `testFilterRedundant` need to check the effort involved. But should be definitely doable. I think originally this was done as Mongo work-around (the database didn't like multiple operations on the same field):
>  Tests that we don't generate multiple constraints on the same column.
>   MongoDB doesn't like it. If there is an '=', it supersedes all other
>   operators. 

But things become more complicated if one has expression  of type  `(b = 2 and a = 1) or (b = 2 and a > 2)`. Ie expression tree has multiple levels. Should optimization occur only on the same level ? More generally, should we be in the business of fixing users queries ?

Re: "fixing" user queries - IMO, it depends on the cost of doing so. If we can without burning too many cycles or complicating things too much on the Calcite side. One of the nice things having these kinda of optimizations in Calcite if we do them cheaply is that it makes it easier to programmatically generate queries without having to think about these things.
Unfortunately due to some major changes that just landed on master, this PR will need to updated. Although you'll see a lot of conflicts, hopefully this should not be too painful to resolve.
@michaelmior Conflicts have been resolved
@beikov Any other thoughts on this? As mentioned before, I'm not an ES user, so it would be good to have a second look from someone who is before merging.
Looks good to me!

Sorry about the closing. I accidentally closed this instead of #744. That's fixed now, but you'll have to reopen this. You should also be able to rebase on top of master and have this PR now be a single commit.
@michaelmior new PR was created: #755
@julianhyde Any thoughts on how much we should care about `testFilterRedundant`?
@michaelmior Comments have been addressed.
Fix has been proposed in #755 (for ES adapter)
@julianhyde thank you so much for reviewing the PR. I have addressed your review comments. Please take a look.

@asereda-gs Actually, maybe I'm missing something, but isn't the simplification you highlighted above from `testFilterRedundant` incorrect? `OK` is not less than `AZ`, so it seems like the predicate should just be simplified to `false`.
We should state that this is about Spark in the message
thank you, updated message

As a short-term solution I would prefer the second option that you have proposed: to use `System.getProperty("java.io.tmpdir")` and remove files with the sources after the class is compiled.

As a long-term solution, I think the code in `SparkHandlerImpl.compile()` method may be rewritten to avoid the creation of temporary files with the sources.

@michaelmior Values of literals don't matter. What happens is operator reduction (precedence) . When there are several comparison expressions on the same attribute `a > 1 and a < 0 and a = 3`. `=` has higher priority over `>` and `<`. It doesn't matter that this expression evaluates to false, it will be reduced to `a=3`. 

See [addPredicate()](https://github.com/apache/calcite/blob/master/mongodb/src/main/java/org/apache/calcite/adapter/mongodb/MongoFilter.java#L134)
My point was that this simplification seems to be incorrect unless I just misunderstand the semantics of the original SQL, which is certainly possible.
